Award.AwardTitle: 2nd International Workshop on the Frontiers of Nanomechanical Systems (FNS/2019)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Second International Workshop on the Frontiers of Nanomechanical Systems (FNS/2019) will be held in Palm Springs, California, 10 to 14 February 2019. This workshop will serve to bring together the international research community engaged in studying nanomechanical systems and is intended to promote exchange of ideas, approaches, and techniques. This should advance collaborative, cross-disciplinary research on nanomechanics and further accelerate the progress in the field, both in terms of fundamental studies and applications. Graduate students and research associates are especially welcome at the conference. To attract them, information about the conference was broadly disseminated, and colleagues were asked to encourage their students and postdocs to attend. There are already 32 graduate students participating in the workshop, which is roughly one-third of the entire participant cohort. The participants are limited to 110 scientists to ensure lively interaction and full participation throughout. The remaining two-thirds of the participants are roughly divided equally between postdocs and senior scientists (either professorial faculty, or professional scientific researchers). The scholarships expected from this grant are intended to be provided to prospective students and postdocs. This should significantly increase and enhance the participation of students and postdocs at the workshop. Steps have been taken to encourage members of the underrepresented groups to attend as well. A measure of success of this effort is that, along with female invited speakers, a female graduate student has been chosen to give an oral contributed talk, which is an exceptional opportunity for a student given the level of the conference.

The workshop FNS/2019 comes from the challenges that are posed by nanomechanical systems. They include, but are not limited to, (i) the occurrence of comparatively strong quantum and classical fluctuations and (ii) the vibration nonlinearity. Along with the invariably present thermal fluctuations, NEMS are subject to nonequilibrium fluctuations. Characterizing and understanding these fluctuations, as well as revealing their consequences is complicated and requires developing new techniques. At the same time, because of the small system size, vibrations with even comparatively small amplitudes become nonlinear, with the nonlinearity often coming into play already for thermal fluctuations. Addressing these challenges requires concerted international effort.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Award Number: 1916003 
PI/co-PI(s): Michael Roukes 

This grant provided partial support for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to enable them to participate in the 2nd International Conference “Frontiers of Nanomechanical Systems” (FNS/2019).

 

Nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) have emerged as a platform for fundamental science and applications. NEMS were first developed in the 1990s and quickly attracted considerable interest.  It was realized that these systems are extremely versatile.  The vibration frequency of NEMS can be tuned not only through the dimensions and the shape of a device, but also in situ by electrostatic and optical means. These small vibrational systems fill in the gap between the microscopic world of molecular vibrations and the world of macroscopic vibrational systems.

The research areas opened by NEMS span from condensed matter physics to statistical physics, quantum many-body physics far from thermal equilibrium, nonlinear dynamics, and nanotechnology. Examples include quantum and classical fluctuations in periodically driven (Floquet) dynamical systems, quantum relaxation of nonequilibrium multilevel systems, microscopic mechanisms and manifestation of linear and nonlinear friction in vibrational systems, many-body localization of vibrational excitations and mechanisms of the localization breaking, strongly nonlinear dynamical response, and a rich and broad group of phenomena related to the coupling of mechanical vibrational modes to each other and to other degrees of freedom, such as electrons, spins, and photons. Some of the problems have been known for decades but could not be accessed in the experimental realm until recently; among these are the quantum Fermi-Pasta-Ulam problem, whereas others are just emerging. Examples of such emerging applications range from qualitatively new means of controlling superconducting qubits to single-spin measurements to a variety of nano- and micro- mechanical sensors, gyroscopes, and clocks.

 

In recent years there have been several major breakthroughs in the studies of NEMS, both experimental and theoretical. To maintain and further accelerate the fast progress in the area, the international workshop series “Frontiers of Nanomechanical Systems” (FNS) was conceived by the organizing committee, comprised of an international panel of researchers. In 2017, the first of these "working meetings" was held in Europe and deemed widely successful. It encompassed the breadth and promise of the field, pointed to new research directions, and resulted in new collaborations. The fast progress in the area requires having such workshops on a regular basis, and the consensus in the community was that the workshops should ideally be held every two years – with venues alternating between Europe, the US, and the Far East. The concept was that a given conference’s support should primarily come from the national funding agencies at the venue. FNS/2019 was the first FNS conference to be held in the US with support from the National Science Foundation. This convergence was declared by all participants to be immensely helpful to accelerating the field and, overall, deemed a great success.
